Delays not good news. Russia is using the sanctions issue to accomplish -- what? Oh, to be a fly on the wall listening to those diplomats having at each other... Dateline 3-1-16 The vote on the U.S.-penned and Chinese-approved United Nations Security Council resolution that calls for strong sanctions on North Korea over its January nuclear test and February long-range missile launch is being delayed by Moscow. The 15-member council was poised to vote on the resolution over the weekend, but Russia, a veto-wielding member of the council, has asked for more time to review it. http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/02/29/russia-holds-up-vote-on-us-drafted-north-korea-sanctions-resolution-at-un.html

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-nuclear-un-idUSKCN0W34QN
http://thephilippinestar.ph/articles/2016-03-02/news/un-security-council-to-vote-on-new-nokor-sanctions/142318 Russia has asked for a procedural delay, but it shouldn't hold up the movement.  Vote Wednesday or Thursday will affirm new sanctions.  (They will not, incidentally, be primarily or perhaps at all about cyberstuff.)

Dropping a bit, because Russia is asking for a procedural delay. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-nuclear-un-idUSKCN0W34QN "The vote, which had been scheduled for Tuesday afternoon, is now planned for 10 a.m. (1500 GMT) on Wednesday, the diplomats said on condition of anonymity."

http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3015574&cloc=joongangdaily%7Chome%7Ctop "This resolution [to sanction DPRK] had been expected to be voted on by the 15-member council over the weekend in New York, and Seoul had anticipated it would be adopted by the end of February at the latest.  . . .  "According to Oh Joon, the South Korean ambassador to the United Nations, “Russia has simply asked for more time to review it, so we do not know how much delay there will be.”  "Russian deputy permanent representative to the United Nations Pyotr Ilyichev told reporters that Moscow needed time to study the resolution as it contains “a vast number of details” and “there are many proposals there that we need to analyze,” reported Russia’s state-run Itar-Tass News Agency Friday. He added that the Russian delegation to the UN would be ready to vote “next week.” "However, some analysts wonder if Russia is stalling not because it finds fault with the resolution but to demonstrate its clout in the wake of Washington and Beijing’s agreement on it. 
. . .
"The resolution, described by U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Samantha Power as the “strongest set of sanctions imposed by the Security Council in more than two decades,” is expected to require for the first time all cargo going in and out of North Korea to be inspected. It will impose financial sanctions targeting North Korean banks and assets, as well as call for sectoral sanctions that could ban exports of North Korean coal and minerals and halt imports of aviation fuel.  "After the draft resolution was shared with council members, it was expected to be put to a vote by as early as Saturday. The other 14 members of the council agreed to the draft resolution. The sole hold-out is Russia.  "Moscow has emphasized from the beginning that sanctions should not lead to a humanitarian or economic collapse of North Korea. 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I hope that this delay by Russia is just a show of power, and not something that is going to result in a veto.  Russia has been a very vocal critic of sanctions (while yet imposing its own against EU agricultural products) so opposing it wouldn't be entirely out of character (though somewhat hypocritical).  I'm growing concerned; if this "delay" drags on beyond the end of this week, I'll be dramatically reducing my forecast.

Russia holding up the approval is suspicious and may be meant as a slap in the face to Obama and China. Maybe. I was at 90% before but this latest move by Russia has to have a lowering effect. It is still very likely and there is plenty of time, but consider an eyebrow raised.

http://world.kbs.co.kr/english/news/news_In_detail.htm?No=117219 The United Nation’s adoption of new sanctions against North Korea will likely take longer than expected as Russia requested time to examine the draft of the new UN resolution.  A vote on the resolution at the UN Security Council is expected as early as Monday, but it could be delayed until Tuesday or Wednesday.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I hope there are not storm clouds gathering:  that Russia won't veto it.  Holding tight for now @ 100%.

Based on the news that the United States and China have agreed on the text of new sanctions on North Korea, I have put the North Korean resolution through my model again which gives a 55% probability of passage.  The US would have provided the draft to UK and France before bringing it to China. In fact, a statement by the Russian Foreign Ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova noted, "As for the draft resolution, I can confirm that we have received the text, it was worked out by the United States that held consultations with a number of countries." (http://tass.ru/en/politics/858942). New Zealand and Spain would also have been consulted to ensure their support. Zakharova also notes that Russia was not consulted on the draft and are asking for time to look at it. This is their suggestion that they would like to bargain. There will definitely be a connection brought up in backroom discussions between US and Russia regarding Russia's support for the North Korea resolution and the Syrian negotiations. There may even be a request for the removal of some sanctions on Russia--however I don't imagine this will happen. Russia is looking to be reintegrated into the international community, however they want to set the terms. Ultimately, however, I think Russia will vote for the sanctions, since Russia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs released a statement on February second protesting the launch and explaining, "We are forced to state that Pyongyang has ignored the global community’s appeals and has again demonstrated provocative disregard of international law." With Russia's support, my model shows that there is a 100% chance of passage.

It's a done deal. All they need is to formalize it. Dateline 2-25-16 Washington and Beijing reached an agreement on a UN draft resolution for fresh sanctions against North Korea over its recent nuclear tests (Reuters). Diplomats did not release details of what the sanctions would target, but South Korea’s foreign ministry said the draft resolution was comprehensive and contained measures that are “stronger than anything in the past” (VOA). The UN Security Council is set to discuss the proposals Thursday. A senior U.S. State Department official will also visit South Korea this week (Yonhap) to hold talks on a joint response to North Korea’s nuclear tests. The draft resolution comes a week after U.S. President Barack Obama imposed new U.S. sanctions freezing assets of those doing business related to North Korea’s nuclear program. North Korea facing new UN sanctions as China and US strike deal, say diplomats: http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/25/north-korea-facing-new-un-sanctions-as-china-and-us-strike-deal-say-diplomats

China is terrified of a collapse of NK because of the tidal wave of refugees it would unleash. That's why they have continued to have been been allies of sorts despite all that weirdness. Fairly or not, the Chinese public tends to see North Koreans as criminals, lazy, pathological liars, incompetent. The Chinese government has been encouraging citizens along the border to form militias, a scary thing for the government to do, suggesting desperation. Also, China has built a bridge to nowhere across the Yalu river bordering the two nations, quite substantial. https://www.nknews.org/2014/10/new-yalu-river-bridge-opening-postponed/  How much reality is there to this view of the North Koreans? Comparison class: South Korea gives lip service to reunification. But the reality is that NK "defectors" require considerable reeducation before they may be integrated into their society.

At the same time, China is terrified of Kim Jong Un and the Kool-Aid consuming religious cult that he heads. This religion, Juche, holds that NK founder Kim Il Sung descended from heaven and all his descendants are divine beings. They also worship a dangerously active volcano on the border between North Korea and China, Mount Paektu (AKA Baekdusan or Changbaishan mountain). Worse, North Korea has been conducting underground nuclear tests dangerously nearby, despite evidence that the giant magma chamber below the volcano has reinflated recently. Now the scientific community is concerned that nuclear tests could trigger a Plinian eruption such as occurred in 946 C.E.  http://www.nature.com/articles/srep21477

"The volcanic eruption in ~946 (namely, the Millennium eruption) had a volcanic explosive index (VEI) of 7 and tephra and pyroclastic flow volume of ~100 km3; it is one of the largest explosive events in human history. The Millennium eruption produced pyroclastic flows of up to 100 m thickness around the caldera and an ash fallout of 4–5 cm in northern Japan." Bottom line: North Korea is huge threat to China, which therefore does not wish to strengthen it, but also does not want it to collapse. The middle way gets ever narrower. Approving increased sanctions could be a way to weaken Kim Jong Un's regime without destroying it.
This question seems like a lock in the affirmative.

Confirming my 100%. http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/23/china-us-talks-un-north-korea-resolution China and US make 'progress' on UN North Korea resolution
Tuesday 23 February 2016 22.34 GMT The United States and China have made progress toward agreeing on a United Nations sanctions resolution to punish North Korea for its recent nuclear tests, the powers’ top diplomats have said. After talks in Washington on Tuesday, China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, and the US secretary of state, John Kerry, said the terms of the resolution were still being evaluated but that they hoped to agree on a draft in the coming days. “I would like to tell you important progress has been made in the consultations and we are looking at the possibility of reaching agreement on a draft resolution and passing it in the near future,” Wang said, while Kerry hailed “significant progress”...

Reaffirming my surmise was likely correct regarding THAAD placement in SK becoming a bargaining chip: http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/02/23/asia-pacific/s-korea-u-s-delay-talks-on-thaad-missile-shield-amid-talks-with-china/#.Vsz65fA8KrV Besides, the Patriot system would be a more effective counter-measure given the trajectories of potential missile launches from the DPRK. However, THAAD and its radar capabilities gives the US an ability to counter effectively any potential missile strike emanating from China, and hence the Chinese concern.  Willing to bet 1 (one) up vote that the THAAD idea is shelved prior to, or simultaneously with, the adoption of any resolution against the DPRK. Any takers? South Korea and US are developing a more coercive unilateral strategy. China and Russia will agree to sanctions if South Korea/US refrain from further military deployment. South Korea is considering nuclear weapons.

www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d50c59aa-d526-11e5-829b-8564e7528e54.html#ixzz40py8yU5y Feb 18th. "China’s strategy to contain North Korea’s nuclear ambitions faces a crucial test in the coming days as the UN Security Council presses ahead with a resolution, and possible new sanctions, against China’s neighbour and sometime ally.
Experts on both sides of the Pacific say Beijing has been surprised by the US’s tough response to Pyongyang’s testing of a nuclear warhead in January and launch this month of a long-range rocket. The US is asking China to impose sweeping economic sanctions on Pyongyang, including an oil embargo “My sense from talking with the Chinese is that they were quite surprised that the US came to them with such a big ask,” says Bonnie Glaser of Washington-based think-tank the Center for International and Strategic Studies. “They were expecting something along the lines of what had been done in the past — a marginally tougher UN Security Council resolution and tough rhetoric, and move on.” "One measure Washington has rolled out is a proposal to base a new anti-missile defence system in South Korea. This has infuriated Beijing, which says the Terminal High-Altitude Air Defence (THAAD) platform could threaten its own nuclear deterrent. "The US has also said it will press ahead with tough unilateral secondary sanctions, with bills working their way through US Congress that could target some Chinese banks and companies working with North Korea. The measures are also intended to stiffen Beijing’s resolve and make it consider cutting off its economic lifeline to Pyongyang.  "Beijing, however, not only fears the consequences of further antagonising North Korea, it is also anxious to prevent the downfall of the regime. “North Korea is a nuclear-armed country on the brink of collapse,” says Zhao Tong, an expert on nuclear disarmament at the Beijing-based Carnegie Tsinghua Centre. “Making it into an enemy is the last thing China wants to see, because China can be directly threatened. I think it is unfair for the international community to make that demand on China.” Beijing appears to have adopted a policy of publicly paying lip-service to tougher sanctions while privately working the levers behind the scenes. Wang Yi, foreign minister, told Reuters in Munich last week that the UN should adopt a resolution to ensure “North Korea will pay the necessary price and to show there is a consequence for its behaviour”. Meanwhile, China’s foreign ministry has been railing against the deployment of THAAD. “Not only is it a direct threat to China’s strategic security interest, but also other countries in the region,” it said on Monday. "The US has been emboldened by the recent Iran nuclear deal, which showed how tough sanctions can work to change the behaviour of “rogue states”. But these arguments do not appear to be working in Beijing, where there is real fear for stability on the Korean peninsula. "When John Kerry . . . urged the Chinese government to embargo oil shipments to North Korea, he was rebuffed by Mr Wang . . . .
"Meanwhile, the opposite approach seems to be in the air in Beijing. Cui Lei, a researcher at the Beijing-based China Institute of International Studies, wrote a widely followed opinion piece in a Singapore newspaper last month advocating treating North Korea similarly to India and Pakistan, which both tested nuclear bombs in 1998.  “It’s now pointless to deny that North Korea has gone nuclear,” Mr Cui wrote. “We should readopt our India-Pakistan approach: acquiescence in North Korea’s nuclearisation, while refusing to legalise it.” . . .  " Mr Zhao of the Carnegie Tsinghua Centre says most Chinese experts recognise the futility of trying to force North Korea into giving up nuclear weapons. He thinks Pyongyang’s current nuclear capability can be implicitly accepted, and that the short-term focus should be freezing the programme.
~~~~~~~

"For more than a month since the North's nuclear test, the Security Council has been struggling in negotiations to come up with a new sanctions resolution on the North because China has been reluctant to impose harsh measures on Pyongyang. Many people have written high probabilities for this question, which I think could be warranted. But I wanted to challenge my own reaction to North Korea’s launch of the satellite on February 7. There is a chance the broad anger over North Korea’s actions might not translate directly into sanctions—particularly by June 1. Several factors will go into its passing—particularly the members’ relationship with the US, attitudes to sanctions and future actions by North Korea itself.
In an effort to answer this question I have attempted to model each of these. To understand the relationship of the countries to the United States, I looked at the countries’ General Assembly votes for the past couple of years (a higher percentage of votes that were the same as the US suggested a closer affinity). I then turned that into a thousand simulations of voting in the Security Council (probabilities of agreeing with sanctions). 
I added an element that took into consideration the chance North Korea would shoot off another rocket or have a nuclear test before June 1, 2016 (my estimate was 50/50). The model last takes into consideration the Security Council members’ post-satellite-launch statements about new sanctions. These then turned into a thousand scenarios in which the resolution either passed, failed or was vetoed. I was then able to calculate the percentage of scenarios in which the resolution passed. This can be updated as members of the Security Council make public statements about the sanctions.

Upgrading it slightly due to recent missile launch. Previously, a successful missile launch was cause for UN sanctions. However, most recently, the nuclear test on Jan. 16 did not result in additional sanctions, leading me to believe that this will also not result in sanctions. China has strong reasons not to approve additional sanctions on North Korea. Mainly because a failed North Korean state will have the biggest impact on China, and relations are already not good--for example, the North Korean girl pop band that left Beijing without performing. However, the threat of the deployment of US missile defense has me wondering which way China will come down--it's something they strongly want to avoid, so it depends on whether they think approving UN sanctions will increase or decrease the chance that US will deploy missile defense. Will increase the chance, but only slightly.

Based on previous actions and reactions by the UN Security council, there is almost a 100% chance the UN Security Council will pass a resolution before 1 June 2016. On average, a resolution has been adopted by the UN Security Council within 26.71 days after the event and the median days elapsed is 23 days. One standard deviation is equal to 17.58 days.
